Tristan Perich, Ensemble 0

              —
              Open Symmetry
            
              (Erased Tapes)
label: Erased Tapes
description:
NYC’s Tristan Perich - the composer/sound artist behind the first ever album issued as a microchip - factors Reich’s phasing minimalism, John McGuire’s Pulse Music, and Ryoji Ikeda’s digital pointillism to logical, hyper-minimalist conclusions in a glittering body of work performed by France’s Ensemble 0

“Perich’s music spans the electronic/classical divide, with explorations that pair string instruments, piano, organ, and other acoustic instrumentation with custom-built 1-bit electronics... more

title_full:
Drew McDowall

              —
              A Thread, Silvered and Trembling
            
              (Dais Records)
label: Dais Records
description:
Coil’s Drew McDowell summons comparisons with his work on the legendary ‘Time Machines’ across an album of electronically processed bagpipe and chamber drone laments, co-produced with Randall Dunn in Brooklyn and using original material recorded by a orchestral quartet

‘A Thread, Silvered and Trembling’ is the 4th album produced during McDowell’s fruitful tenure with NYC label, Dais. Nearly a decade since he emerged solo under his own name with ‘Collapse’, his new album drops... more

title_full:
Geordie Greep

              —
              The New Sound
            
              (Rough Trade)
label: Rough Trade
description:
black midi frontman Geordie Greep muddles cabaret vocalisations and Steely Dan-style virtuosity with the bombastic chaos of Frank Zappa on his hyperactive, exhaustingly zany debut album.

If you've already got a taste for Greep's oddball delivery - never mind his love of complicated, prog-strength musical proficiency - then you'll no doubt wanna peer into 'The New Sound', but be warned, the Mighty Boosh reverence isn't confined to the title alone. Greep doesn't approach his solo... more

artist: Louis Cole, Metropole Orkest,  Jules Buckley
title_full:
Louis Cole, Metropole Orkest,  Jules Buckley

              —
              nothing
            
              (Brainfeeder)
label: Brainfeeder
description:
Louis Cole, Jules Buckley and the Metropole Orkest team up on 'nothing'.

"A raucous musical trip that veers from funk-fuelled mayhem to sombre balladry with the orchestra dialling up the emotional power to 11.

Louis Cole is an LA-based singer-songwriter and sickeningly talented multi-instrumentalist with a strong DIY aesthetic. Thundercat describes him as “one of Los Angeles's greatest musicians”. He composed a suite of brand new music for this project – bigger, bolder, and more... more

label: Sacred Bones Records
description:
NYC noise rockers Uniform return to Sacred Bones with their most transcendent set yet - four heaving genre-fluxing movements that burrow into the darkest depths of the psyche.

Clear that he wanted to approach difficult subject matter - such as eating disorders, mania, self-hatred and self-discovery - Uniform vocalist Michael Berdan reached out to two writers, Maggie Siebert and B.R. Yeager, who helped him "present a portrait of mental and physical illness as vividly terrifying as anything in... more

title_full:
shellac

              —
              To All Trains
            
              (Touch and Go Records)
label: Touch and Go Records
description:
Long-running post-hardcore/noise-rock heroes Shellac bow out with their explosive sixth studio album; their first in ten years, it's a angular, technical, lyrical whirlwind packed with sharp asides, buzzsaw riffs and fuzzed-out nods to the US rock 'n roll canon. 

When Steve Albini died of a heart attack earlier in May, Shellac were only ten days away from releasing 'To All Trains'. The idiosyncratic engineer, guitarist, singer and songwriter left behind a catalogue that's helped maintain the pebbly... more

label: Constellation
description:
Montréal's Vicky Mettler follows up 2022's quietly brilliant 'Crease' with another accomplished fusion of jagged riffs and collapsing alien electronics - somewhere between Scott Walker, PJ Harvey and latter-day AE, it's like little else out there.

'Crease' took us by surprise, and 'Spine' is even more convincing. Mettler's production has shifted further into the void this time around; the foley glitches and synth squelches that helped elevate her debut are even bolder this time around. Her voice... more
